post_id: they don't have that \"killing form\".
the entire \"slow feed\" program is necessary because horses have been meal fed.  Once they get transitioned and are self-regulating as nature intended
forum_user_id: they naturally slow down because they feel safe to do so knowing that the low-calorie high fiber forage is available to them at all times.  IR horses are a separate subject because their systems have been compromised and they typically aren't able to self-regulate any longer.  Meal feeding is a leading cause of IR because every time a horse gets a meal it has an insulin spike which is causing the disease.,Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:18.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/18.0,markdown1360,5762,74873787c8a41b0f6503a012bd5730ff09411ac6,1359497597,0,0,0,0,The setup where the research was done had \"crew barns\" which housed 3 horses each. Two enzymes are lost through muscle cell walls
forum_user_id: creatine kinase and aspartate aminotranferase. The rise in these reflects the severity of the muscle damage.  With severe muscle damage myoglobin is released into the blood. It's a large molecule and is excreted via the kidneys causing the classic dark coloured urine. Muscle damage causes lactic acid to be released which is responsible for the cramping of the muscles.

post_id: it's easier for me to add a little rice bran to my TB's diet than try to figure out how to balance a complete feed. Experience has shown me that about 1/2 pound per day during the winter will help him maintain condition. That's not so much that the cost factor matters. And yes
forum_user_id: mine is balanced to a 1:1 Ca:P ratio. I would still be careful if I were feeding a lot

post_id: and then probably back off slightly once he's in good condition. Many rice bran manufacturer's recommend no more than 1/2 pound per day
forum_user_id: but I have also heard people say that they feed up to a couple of pounds a day and don't see any ill effects.

post_id: earlier pharmacokinetic studies of metformin adminstration to horses showed little or no measurable metformin in the blood following oral administration meaning that it has minimal bioavailability. An abstract presented at the ACVIM Forum in June 2012 in New Orleans from a group in the UK showed that metformin administered orally decreased gut absorption of glucose. My question was
forum_user_id: where did it go? Does it then pass on into the LI to potentially cause problems? John's response proposed that the gut cells may actually increase their utilization of that glucose so that there is no excessive glucose to present to the LI. Guess we will have to wait for additional research to get that answer.?,Mozilla/5.0 (iPad; CPU OS 6_1 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/536.26 (KHTML

forum_user_id: like Gecko) Chrome/24.0.1312.57 Safari/537.17,markdown2846,9669,259f4b732bffcbacfdf407c59662e3c696564953,1360034666,0,0,0,0,Yes that is true.  TO MY UNDERSTANDING SO FAR... Ideally the laminitic horse would be turned out during the night rather than during high intensity daylight hours and in a paddock where the pasture is still using the WSC (which contains the fructan that causes GIT upset and can trigger laminitis) to grow (around 6cm tall) to ensure the forage they are consuming is has the lowest possible levels of WSC. The pasture would also be regularly topped/mowen to encourage the grass to continue to grow and therefore use the WSC (and fructans) to grow decreasing the levels the horse consumes. This considers the role of photosynthesis/amount of daylight/and stage of growth however in terms of temperature affecting the levels of WSC

post_id: hay is becoming much more scarce as corn here in the US is in high demand from ethanol fuel production.  MANY of my former hay suppliers have quit and turned their fields to corn production because its less labor intensive with a higher profit margin. A farmer can also buy crop insurance on corn.  Crop insurance is NOT available for hay.    Add in climate change.  We are experiencing unusually HOT summers and went through a terrible drought this past summer that actually resulted in several farmers in our region to give up.

post_id: may be a healthy balanced horse has a better instinct ?? I have recently fed mag chloride it has some very convincing docs as a trans  dermal for humans    And some bare footers have been using it as a suppliment . you dissolve it and add to feed  increasing dose till the manure softens then back off  . It is expensive and I recently read a comparison of mag supps and mag ox came up very well .  I think good old fashion soaking of a hoof in Epsom salts probably does some thing similar to the transdermal mag chloride.  Way cheaper  my \" footy \" welsh pony loves standing with his feet in the buckets  I throw in a bit if electric soda too and it really help soften the dead sole which they seem to overproduce  and once removed seems to give relief  some times they exfoliate the whole sole and the dead frog tissue ! Almost instant relief ...  I then follow a standard veterinary homeopathic dosing protocol of calc Fluor 30c daily for at least 4 weeks or more plus a few weekly doses of thuja 1m  the calc fluo is a none conditioner  for the bones inside the hoof capsule that must be compromised by poor blood flow ands the thuja addresses the distortion and tendency for the hoof to want to grow distorted. The curling  you see in a way over grown hoof  which I know  happens  in part mechanically with the separation but there is more as I often see curling of feathers too and of course the extream is in Cushing coats !  Thuja is known as a homeopathic for vaccinosis   A whole other problem ! ,Mozilla/5.0 (iPhone; CPU iPhone OS 6_0_1 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/536.26 (KHTML

I feed her a concentrated fed with free choice alfalfa/orchard grass mix pasture bales. when she is stalled she get alfalfa hay. Knock on wood

[Instructors please help out if I have got things wrong]

it seems that oat starch is more easily digestible than other grain starches - something like 84% of the starch. Therefore any processing of the oats is likely to produce relatively little increase in starch digestion. The chewing of grain by the horse breaks it down so that the enzymes can access the starch
forum_user_id: so that horses with poor teeth will not grind it so much and the enzymes will not be able to access the starch so easily

post_id: why are you trying to discuss the 10% rule and fructans in the same sentence? They have nothing to do with each other.

I looked up Equi-Analysis's feed tables. The normal range (one standard deviation each way) of WSC for grass hay is about 7-16%. This is much lower than the approximately 30% figure that is being kicked around as the level that may induce laminitis. It's probably a combination of ignoring the extremes and the loss of fructans during drying of the hay that results in only moderate levels being shown.
but my concern is with the overall WSC and the factors that cause it to go up or down. Whether it's fructans or sugars that cause hind gut overload from pasture probably does not matter to most of us

I currently go to University and tutors in the field of science ask questions in two ways. The first is the sneaky trick question that makes you question what you know. Many people get this type of question wrong because they do not know the content well enough. The second type is the straightforward question that many get wrong because they read and interpret it as a trick question. The best way to do well in these sort of quizzes I think is to review the notes

forum_user_id: like Gecko) Version/6.0 Mobile/10A523 Safari/8536.25,markdown3788,9581,301363b57f540ad208c0c9b4a52ba06b688d8d60,1360587770,0,0,0,0,I find worm counts are an incredibly useful tool in worm management. Often just one horse in a field has a much higher burden. Worm counts help to pinpoint where the issues lie and how to rectify the problem without overuse of chemicals in horses that do not have a worm problem. This in turn helps to reduce worm resistance. Best practice in my opinion is good grassland management (avoid horsesick pastures) coupled with worm counts and strategic worming. forum_user_id: it is doing your horse more harm than good.  People will continue to defend its practice and swear by its results even though scientifically proven otherwise. it is well-established that IR is more common in certain breeds -- mostly ones that evolved or were bred to survive in environments without much food around at least some of the time...desert climates

post_id: domesticated horses tend to be fed rations that are broadly excessive with respect to the metabolic requirements for the level of physical activity to which they are subjected
forum_user_id: \" he says. Ironically, he also points out that starvation can induce IR, as can stress, inflammation, an excess of the hormone cortisol and drugs such as dexamethasone, whichmimic the action of cortisol.Lynn, as awareness of this problem has increased dramatically since I wrote that article (it was one of the first if not the first in the mainstream media), the breed-relatedness (genetic predisposition) has become much more well established. Anyone familiar with the symptoms of IR can look around at the horses and ponies they know and spot the IR ones, and chances are pretty good you'll see it in a lot of ponies -- so much so that it is generally recommended to feed the \"IR diet\" to ANY pony, whether they are exhibiting the symptoms or not. I see it everywhere in ponies, donkeys, super common problem in morgans, Spanish horses...far too many, but definitely breed predilections. I'm sure someone out there has an IR TB, but I personally have never met one!

post_id: the lack of circulation in the hoof means that necrotic tissue is not properly removed from the hoof while its shod. Removing the shoes then restores this circulation. So whether a hoof will develop abscesses or not is dependent on how much necrotic tissue is in the hoof and whether it can clear the tissue in the normal way or not.

forum_user_id: they would be easy meat! In  our case we feed every morning and every evening but anywhere between 6 and 8 am or pm. But clearly they can become creatures of routine very easily as shown by those who start banging their stable doors if the feed is a few minutes late! post_id: just like a teacup

I put her into a small feedlot that is used for a couple cows in the winter. It was slightly overgrown around the edges with a tall stem grass. She would eat the tops off and that was it. I also gave her a grass hay & slowly added more to allow her to forage anytime. Since she was used to eating a small amount each day I really didnt want to mess up her GIT.  She was in the feedlot for a week. Attached to the lot is a small pasture I could let her have access to when ready. After the week I would lead her to the pasture to eat but would keep hold of her lead. I did that for a total of 1 hour a day for about 3 days then I let her out free in the pasture for 2 to 4 hours a day for about 2 weeks (between 10am and 2pm) Thats what worked the best for me after that I would just lock her in the lot at night & let her out in the am. Once she had grass regularily she wouldnt touch the hay. Now she is on grass all the time.  She went from a weak little thing to quite a fire cracker.,Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 9.0; Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; Trident/5.0),markdown4729,12924,52444afc380d55a774ff330e573bbf9efbc57f7f,1361199647,0,0,0,0,Hi Joan - but (in humans
